data.title: master/slave GDScript keyword name choice might be unfortunate
data.body:
There's been something of a trend towards moving away from “master” and “slave” terminology, because of its associations with, well, slavery: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Master-slave_%28technology%29#Appropriateness_of_usage

Besides that issue, sometimes alternative naming choices are clearer anyway (e.g. “leader/follower”), especially to people from a non-technical background. It's not entirely clear to me from the names what they mean. My first guess was it means an authoritative server (“master”) and replicating client (“slave”) relationship, but I'm not quite sure.

At the risk of starting a flame war, it might be worth changing them. If they were to be changed, better to do it now while they're not in a stable release.

data.title: Update ENet to use Godot sockets.
data.body:
This PR adds an ENet implementation using Godot Sockets.
The files changed in enet library are:
- `host.c`: one line to allow IPv6
- `protocol.c`: three lines to allow IPv6
- `enet.h`: Add a function and change ENetAddress structure to allow for IPv6, include the files that implement the socket functions for the library using Godot sockets (two new files `godot.cpp` and `enet/godot.h`).

It also adds non-blocking mode for PacketPeerUDP (only available via C++) so ENet should be almost as performant as with the raw sockets.

With this PR builtin enet gets full IPv4 and IPv6 support.
When compiling with `builtin_enet=no` the module will still work but will be IPv4 only as per the upstream library.

Fixes #6992 

@punto- you might want to have a look at this :wink: 

PS: You can test it with https://github.com/Faless/gd-bomber-3 which is an ugly 3.0 ported version of the multiplayer bomber in the official demo.

data.title: Sub-inherited scene is not updated properly in the editor
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1 and 3.0 probably too, after applying #7978 or #7979, respectively (without them the issues are much more serious)


**Issue description:**
If a scene indirectly inherits another, it doesn't get properly updated in the editor. The editor won't trigger the reload of the most derived scene, but will apply partially the changes made to the base scene.


**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a scene hierarchy (inheritance) like this: __C__ inherits __B__ which inherits __A__.
2. Open __A__ and __C__ in the editor.
3. Add some node to __A__.
4. Switch to __C__. Notice it isn't reloaded.
5. Reload manually with _Revert Scene_.
6. Switch back to __A__.
7. Remove the node you created.
8. Switch again to __C__. Notice how the node you created now appears as owned.
9.a. If you reload __C__ again, everything will be in place (with the phantom node gone).
9.b. If instead you save __C__, the node will be commited to the scene as if it had been created there initially.


**Link to minimal example project:**
Maybe one day.

data.title: Double-inheritance duplicates nodes
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1.2 (and last 2.1 branch)


**Issue description:**
I have a scene hierarchy composed of three scenes: __C__ inherits __B__ which inherits __A__.
When opening __C__ in the editor I can see some (but not all) nodes from __A__ shown as if owned by __C__.
If I save the scene, then all those problematic nodes get saved to the __C__'s scene file.
If then I re-open __C__ I can see in the tree the nodes that were duplicated when saving. So every time I save my scene is getting additional copies of the nodes from __A__ being wrongly identified as owned (not inherited).

Strage enough, if I remove some nodes from __B__ and reload __C__, at a certain point the issue starts to apply to less nodes. Not every node I remove from __B__ has this effect.

Also when saving __C__ I get a bunch of errors like this:
```
ERROR: SceneState::get_property_value: Condition ' p_node<0 ' is true. returned: Variant()
   At: scene\resources\packed_scene.cpp:1032
```

Some clue about where is the problem in my scenes or in Godot's source?

**Please! This is a show stopper for me.**

EDIT: One more thing I've found is that I if write a script that loads __C__ and saves it, it gets saved correcly. So the process of packing/unpacking seems to be the place to look.

**Steps to reproduce:**
~~Haven't found yet. Just happens with my game. I've tried to create a minimal project that shows the issue, but this doesn't happen there.~~

UPDATE:
~~At least after applying the work-in-progress fix #7978, I can reproduce it by loading an scene and another that inherits indirectly from it. When saving the former, the latter is updated making a mess.~~

A possible reason is that when the scene is saved, its state is recreated and it no longer has a node path cache as when it's firstly loaded. See https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/master/scene/resources/packed_scene.cpp#L78

**Link to minimal example project:**
Haven't been able to isolate.

data.title: Remove_and_skip crashes if the node have children
data.body:
**Ubuntu 16.10 - Godot version: 2.1.2 stable**


**Issue description:**
Using Node.remove_and_skip crashes and closes the game window if the node have children, this message is shown on the terminal:
```
ERROR: operator[]: Condition ' p_index<0 || p_index>=size() ' is true. returned: aux
   At: core/vector.h:132.
```

It was supposed to 

> Remove a node and set all its children as children of the parent node (if exists). All even subscriptions that pass by the removed node will be unsubscribed

according to docs http://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/classes/class_node.html#class-node-remove-and-skip.

**Steps to reproduce:**
 - Use Node method `remove_and_skip` on a node with children.

**Link to minimal example project:**
Press any key to trigger remove_and_skip on the "parent" node.
[removeandskipbug.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/824719/removeandskipbug.zip)

data.title: simple 2D (pong) game guide docs suggestion
data.body:
IMHO, I don't think that the step-by-step intro to godot docs should assume the reader has any experience with Python. Whilst this page:

http://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/tutorials/step_by_step/simple_2d_game.html

Does a good job of explaining each step of building up the script, it doesn't include a complete script code listing and nor does it explain that every line of code printed after 

`func _process(delta):`

Should be indented so as to be part of the _process function. Whilst this may be obvious to those who have experience with python, it likely won't be so obvious to those who don't.

data.title: Editor: Dim UI when a WindowDialog is shown.
data.body:
Darkens the editor on WindowDialog popups.

This adds the following new Editor settings:

- `interface/dim_editor_on_dialog_popup (true)` # Enable/Disable editor dimming
- `interface/dim_amount (0.6)` # Percentage of how much the editor will be darkened (0-1)
- `interface/dim_transition_time (0.11)` # The duration (in seconds) of the color blending effect (0-1), 0 is instant.

Please test this thoroughly, I haven't yet seen a case where it fails to work properly but I'm sure I didn't test all windows of the editor :P 
Closes #7900 

![darken2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8281916/23625863/fb87b2e8-02aa-11e7-8da5-2adb2d1dbd53.gif)

data.title: PR 7565 + polish
data.body: What shall I do with _master_?

data.title: Openvr module for Godot 2.x
data.body:
Ok, I've decided to put this in as a pull request because the place this is in now it would be good to get some feedback and it may be useful for others. It is at a stage where its a workable solution however so far I've been treating this as a prototype. My plan is to build a small demo with this over the coming weeks as time permits and fix up some more rough edges. 

Note that this uses the camera changes in PR #7778 and as that is still an outstanding PR I'm guessing those changes will be mixed in with this :)

I've also got a small test godot project over here:
https://github.com/BastiaanOlij/TestOpenVR
Nothing exciting, just a few blocks and objects for the lighthouse boxes and controllers but it shows how this module works. 

There are still a number of rough edges especially around compiling and linking. OpenVR, regardless of suggesting its Open, is partially closed source and tied into SteamVR so it requires linking with a library and inclusion of a DLL. My knowledge of Scons is still very much lacking in order to clean this up. Also I've only made this work on 64bit Windows. In theory OpenVR should support Linux and Mac but I have no access to Linux atm and I haven't gotten it to work with a Mac (mainly because the Vive refuses to work with it). 

The other area that needs improvement is the way the render targets are output to OpenVR, its workable but not pretty. Godot for obvious reasons expect the render targets to be used further on in its pipeline, not redirected to some external device. In the same line of thought, the output to screen needs more work, with VR requiring a high framerate (90fps - 120fps) to prevent motion sickness v-sync needs to be turned off but as a result we're also rendering at that frame rate to screen. Total overkill as we're only rendering to screen for spectators. 

Finally, because I attempted to implement this as a module I made spatial nodes that are automatically repositioned by OpenVRs tracking information. It was particularly nice as this allowed me to show the interaction in the editor. I later abandoned that idea because OpenVR turned out to be very unstable when both the editor and when running your project tried to output to the HMD. So OpenVR is only accessed when running your project. In that line of thought an approach similar to how controllers are handled in the input classes may be a better approach. I think this is worth discussing especially as this may allow us to implement modules for different VR SDKs which store the relevant tracking data into a centralised array maintained by the input class.  

Anyway, looking forward to getting some feedback. My end goal is to redo this work for Godot 3 from scratch, take anything people offer here into account and come up with a production ready solution.

data.title: 2.2 (Adding multiple classpath and gradle plugins)
Crash on exit iOS application
Old type names / inconsistency in typenames exposed to ClassDB
data.body:
I'm doing stuff for the DLScript module. I'm generating wrapper classes in C++.

I noticed following problems:

`Control::get_minimum_size()` is registered twice: once as `virtual`, once as `const`. This is a problem because `ClassDB::get_method()` can't handle overloaded functions / functions with the same name.


[PoolFloatVector](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/5dbf1809c6e3e905b94b8764e99491e608122261/core/variant.cpp#L169), that's `PoolRealArray` now.

[RawArray](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/5dbf1809c6e3e905b94b8764e99491e608122261/core/bind/core_bind.cpp#L2081) is `PoolByteArray` now.

If a method returns `Variant` it's registered as `void` in ClassDB.

[AudioServerState](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/5dbf1809c6e3e905b94b8764e99491e608122261/servers/audio_server.cpp#L991) is being passed to AudioServer::set_state, but the type `AudioServerState` does not exist.

--------------------------------

I'll fix this as soon as possible, just want to note it down here.

data.title: Multiple Sprite3D being rendered in weird order
data.body:
Systems tested:
http://pasted.co/ca4970b9
http://pasted.co/d1a10e38

Version: v2.1.2.stable.official

**Issue description:**
Placing a big Sprite3D in front of a small Sprite3D may render the big one in front of the small one, depending on the view angle.

Adding a TestCube between both sprites creates a curious side-effect, here the big sprite on the back is rendered in front of the small sprite, except where the latter overlaps the TestCube, where the small sprite is rendered as expected.

It happens on both the editor and when running.

**Steps to reproduce:**
![Reproduce](http://i.giphy.com/l0IybikWcfYcFyoFO.gif)

**Link to minimal example project:**
[Issue.tar.gz](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/820131/Issue.tar.gz)

data.title: Fix build with VC++
Can't access script methods of instanced scene
data.body:
<!--
README: Incompatibilities and broken features in the current master branch / 3.0-alpha
are known and expected due to important refactoring work, so no need to report them for now. Thanks!
-->

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux
latest git


**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->

I have a scene (a single button) with a script attached to its root:

`dock.tscn:`
```
[gd_scene load_steps=2 format=2]

[ext_resource path="res://addons/dock/dock.gd" type="Script" id=1]

[node name="Button" type="Button"]

margin_right = 12.0
margin_bottom = 20.0
rect_clip_content = false
mouse_filter = 0
toggle_mode = false
enabled_focus_mode = 2
shortcut = null
group = null
text = "Test Button"
flat = false
script = ExtResource( 1 )
```

`dock.gd:`
```gdscript
extends Button

func _ready():
	pass

func test():
	print("test")
```

 The methods of the instanced script aren't accessible.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Trying to access it like this

`dock_plugin.gd`
```gdscript
tool
extends EditorPlugin

var dock

func _enter_tree():
	dock = preload("res://addons/dock/dock.tscn").instance()
	dock.test()

	add_control_to_dock( DOCK_SLOT_LEFT_UL, dock)


func _exit_tree():
	remove_control_from_docks( dock )
	dock.free()
```
results in the following error:
```
SCRIPT ERROR: _enter_tree: Invalid call. Nonexistent function 'test' in base 'Button (dock.gd)'.
   At: res://addons/dock/dock_plugin.gd:8.
```


**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

[dock-test.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/820007/dock-test.zip)

data.title: Some inconsistencies in classDB's bindings
data.body:
Hi,

I'm currently using classDB introspection system to generate bindings for godot-python.
I've found some troubles in the bindings:

- audio_server.cpp: `AudioServer.set_state` and `AudioServer.generate_state` are mark to return a `AudioServerState`, but there is no reference of this type anywhere
- core_bind.cpp: `_Marshalls::base64_to_raw` is marked to return a `RawArray` which is an out-of-date alias to `PoolByteArray` (i.e. `PoolVector<uint8_t>`)
- visual_script: `VisualScriptPropertySet` properties' names start with `property/...`, this is a pretty strange name given slash is not a valid variable character for most languages (including C++ and GDscript) so doing `VisualScriptPropertySet.property/set_mode` is impossible...
- control.cpp: `Control.get_minimum_size` is binded two times (has a virtual and a regular method)
- packet_peer.cpp: `PacketPeer.put_packet` is declared has returning an `Error` type which is never defined within classdb

I'm ready to send a PR to solve this (seems all minor issues to me, but some for them like the `property/...` stuff is more like something I didn't catch...)

data.title: really fixed PTRCALL now
data.body: Forgot to build with PTRCALL_ENABLED last time. Duh. This fixes it. For real.

data.title: Added PowerState casting operator to Variant
data.body: Without it Godot does not build with PTRCALL_ENABLED

data.title: Fix KinematicBody2D motion issues + KinematicBody2D.test_move_from() (2.1)
data.body:
~~Adds `KinematicBody2D.set_enable_motion_accumulation()` so subsequent calls to `move()`, `move_to()` and `revert_motion()` during the same fixed frame get accumulated. (See #7951 for more info.)~~

~~Motion accumulation is disabled by default so everything works as always unless this fixing behavior is explicitly enabled.~~

~~Also adds some APIs to the physics servers and the kinematic body for finer control.~~

~~Fixes #7951.~~

UPDATE: Cleaner solution:

Got part of the fix from 5fc084c28e912c54bf64645df3e6cf2cd2c30be6 (but there in _master_ is still something broken that will get a PR)
Added an engine setting to enable the fix (__physics_2d/motion_fix_enabled__) which is false by default so the default behavior is the same as always
Added `KinematicBody2D.test_move_from()` to have in 2.1 an useful method as the plain `move()` is for 3.0, whch already has the `from` parameter
